issue.title: feat(core): support end-user extensions in the rule definitions
issue.body:
This change introduces a user extensions for rule definitions.

**Problem**
As a user of Spectral, we want to keep additional metadata close to the rule definitions. E.g. when this rule is introduced, who is responsible, etc.

**Solution**
As it's not possible to foresee what kind of metadata users might need, therefore introducing additional fields with a concrete specificity doesn't scale and will pollute the Rule interface.

The main idea behind this solution is to give Spectral users a way to define custom extensions similar to `x-` attributes in OpenAPI documents. In this change, the new property `extensions` is introduced in the rule type which can be used by users to define any user's payload inside.

Alternative idea for the property name: `metadata`.

**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [ ] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

**Additional information**
The new field is not supported by the `print` utility. As the type of the extensions properties is unknown, it might be challenging to print it via `treeify`. Since this utility is only used for testing purposes, it seems to be okay to ignore the new property in this utility function. The similar situation is with `toJSON()`.

comment.body:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-ruleset-bundler/v/1.5.0)

issue.title: feat(core): support end-user extensions in the rule definitions
issue.body:
This change introduces a user extensions for rule definitions.

**Problem**
As a user of Spectral, we want to keep additional metadata close to the rule definitions. E.g. when this rule is introduced, who is responsible, etc.

**Solution**
As it's not possible to foresee what kind of metadata users might need, therefore introducing additional fields with a concrete specificity doesn't scale and will pollute the Rule interface.

The main idea behind this solution is to give Spectral users a way to define custom extensions similar to `x-` attributes in OpenAPI documents. In this change, the new property `extensions` is introduced in the rule type which can be used by users to define any user's payload inside.

Alternative idea for the property name: `metadata`.

**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [ ] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

**Additional information**
The new field is not supported by the `print` utility. As the type of the extensions properties is unknown, it might be challenging to print it via `treeify`. Since this utility is only used for testing purposes, it seems to be okay to ignore the new property in this utility function. The similar situation is with `toJSON()`.

issue.title: Unable to use a spectral file located in Enterprise Github with a token parameter
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When trying to use a spectral lint file that requires a token param, Spectral throws an unexpected error

```
Error running Spectral!
Error #1: Unexpected token (Note that you need plugins to import files that are not JavaScript)
          at error            …hared/rollup.js:198  base = Object.assig…
          at error            …red/rollup.js:12555  return error(props);
          at tryParse         …red/rollup.js:12932  return this.error({ 
          at setSource        …red/rollup.js:12837  ast = this.tryParse…
          at addModuleSource  …red/rollup.js:22311  module.setSource(aw…
```

**To Reproduce**

1. Create a GitHub repository and place a spectral file there, like this:
    * style.yaml
```
extends: spectral:oas
rules:
  oas3-api-costcenter:
    description: There must be x-cost-center.
    given: $
    severity: error
    then:
      field: x-cost-center
      function: truthy

  oas3-api-businessid:
    description: There must be x-business-id.
    given: $
    severity: error
    then:
      field: x-business-id
      function: truthy
``` 
2. Go to the raw view of that spectral file and copy the url, it should have a token in it
2. Create a local folder with a "src" folder and a basic api-schema.json file that has an oas schema
3. Run this CLI command 'spectral lint "./src/api-schema.json" --ruleset {url with token from step 2} --verbose'
4. See error
```
Error running Spectral!
Error #1: Unexpected token (Note that you need plugins to import files that are not JavaScript)
          at error            …hared/rollup.js:198  base = Object.assig…
          at error            …red/rollup.js:12555  return error(props);
          at tryParse         …red/rollup.js:12932  return this.error({ 
          at setSource        …red/rollup.js:12837  ast = this.tryParse…
          at addModuleSource  …red/rollup.js:22311  module.setSource(aw…
```

**Expected behavior**
I would expect that Spectral would be able to ingest this file as a standard curl command shows the file as it should be.  Additionally, if I pull the file down locally and put it in the repo, it runs fine.

**Environment (remove any that are not applicable):**
 - Library version: Spectral v6.5.1
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Browser: n/a

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

comment.body:
:tada: This issue has been resolved in version @stoplight/spectral-cli-v6.6.0 :tada:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-cli/v/6.6.0)

Your **[semantic-release](https://github.com/semantic-release/semantic-release)** bot :package::rocket:

issue.title: Peer dependency incorrectly met when using Yarn 3.x
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I upgraded to yarn 3.x and now I have a project that is showing this error 

```sh
$ yarn install
➤ YN0000: ┌ Resolution step
➤ YN0002: │ @stoplight/spectral-cli@npm:6.3.0 doesn't provide rollup (p8903b), requested by @rollup/plugin-commonjs
➤ YN0000: │ Some peer dependencies are incorrectly met; run yarn explain peer-requirements <hash> for details, where <hash> is the six-letter p-prefixed code
➤ YN0000: └ Completed
```

**To Reproduce**

Create a project with `@stoplight/spectral-cli` as a devDependency and run `$ yarn install` with the latest version of yarn.

**Expected behavior**
No peer dependency error

**Environment (remove any that are not applicable):**
 - OS: macOS

comment.body:
:tada: This issue has been resolved in version @stoplight/spectral-cli-v6.6.0 :tada:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-cli/v/6.6.0)

Your **[semantic-release](https://github.com/semantic-release/semantic-release)** bot :package::rocket:

issue.title: refactor(rulesets): remove unused rules style param
issue.body:
**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [x] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

We have discussed removing the style parameter becasue it has not proved very useful compared to simply using Error and Warning, or splitting rules into multiple rulesets for different purposes or strictnesses. 

I had thought this would be a breaking change, but the more I look at it, the less I can see it being used in any way for anything. Perhaps we use it in Studio but as far as Spectral is concerned I am not sure this is breaking. Rulesets will still validate because JSON Schema doesn't care about extra properties.

**Screenshots**

If applicable, add screenshots or gifs to help demonstrate the changes. If not applicable, remove this screenshots section before creating the PR.

**Additional context**

Add any other context about the pull request here. Remove this section if there is no additional context.

comment.body:

issue.title: Unable to use a spectral file located in Enterprise Github with a token parameter
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When trying to use a spectral lint file that requires a token param, Spectral throws an unexpected error

```
Error running Spectral!
Error #1: Unexpected token (Note that you need plugins to import files that are not JavaScript)
          at error            …hared/rollup.js:198  base = Object.assig…
          at error            …red/rollup.js:12555  return error(props);
          at tryParse         …red/rollup.js:12932  return this.error({ 
          at setSource        …red/rollup.js:12837  ast = this.tryParse…
          at addModuleSource  …red/rollup.js:22311  module.setSource(aw…
```

**To Reproduce**

1. Create a GitHub repository and place a spectral file there, like this:
    * style.yaml
```
extends: spectral:oas
rules:
  oas3-api-costcenter:
    description: There must be x-cost-center.
    given: $
    severity: error
    then:
      field: x-cost-center
      function: truthy

  oas3-api-businessid:
    description: There must be x-business-id.
    given: $
    severity: error
    then:
      field: x-business-id
      function: truthy
``` 
2. Go to the raw view of that spectral file and copy the url, it should have a token in it
2. Create a local folder with a "src" folder and a basic api-schema.json file that has an oas schema
3. Run this CLI command 'spectral lint "./src/api-schema.json" --ruleset {url with token from step 2} --verbose'
4. See error
```
Error running Spectral!
Error #1: Unexpected token (Note that you need plugins to import files that are not JavaScript)
          at error            …hared/rollup.js:198  base = Object.assig…
          at error            …red/rollup.js:12555  return error(props);
          at tryParse         …red/rollup.js:12932  return this.error({ 
          at setSource        …red/rollup.js:12837  ast = this.tryParse…
          at addModuleSource  …red/rollup.js:22311  module.setSource(aw…
```

**Expected behavior**
I would expect that Spectral would be able to ingest this file as a standard curl command shows the file as it should be.  Additionally, if I pull the file down locally and put it in the repo, it runs fine.

**Environment (remove any that are not applicable):**
 - Library version: Spectral v6.5.1
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Browser: n/a

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

comment.body:
:tada: This issue has been resolved in version @stoplight/spectral-cli-v6.6.0 :tada:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-cli/v/6.6.0)

issue.title: Peer dependency incorrectly met when using Yarn 3.x
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I upgraded to yarn 3.x and now I have a project that is showing this error 

```sh
$ yarn install
➤ YN0000: ┌ Resolution step
➤ YN0002: │ @stoplight/spectral-cli@npm:6.3.0 doesn't provide rollup (p8903b), requested by @rollup/plugin-commonjs
➤ YN0000: │ Some peer dependencies are incorrectly met; run yarn explain peer-requirements <hash> for details, where <hash> is the six-letter p-prefixed code
➤ YN0000: └ Completed
```

**To Reproduce**

Create a project with `@stoplight/spectral-cli` as a devDependency and run `$ yarn install` with the latest version of yarn.

**Expected behavior**
No peer dependency error

**Environment (remove any that are not applicable):**
 - OS: macOS

comment.body:
:tada: This issue has been resolved in version @stoplight/spectral-cli-v6.6.0 :tada:

issue.title: refactor(rulesets): remove unused rules style param
issue.body:
**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [x] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

We have discussed removing the style parameter becasue it has not proved very useful compared to simply using Error and Warning, or splitting rules into multiple rulesets for different purposes or strictnesses. 

I had thought this would be a breaking change, but the more I look at it, the less I can see it being used in any way for anything. Perhaps we use it in Studio but as far as Spectral is concerned I am not sure this is breaking. Rulesets will still validate because JSON Schema doesn't care about extra properties.

**Screenshots**

If applicable, add screenshots or gifs to help demonstrate the changes. If not applicable, remove this screenshots section before creating the PR.

**Additional context**

Add any other context about the pull request here. Remove this section if there is no additional context.

issue.title: feat(core): support end-user extensions in the rule definitions
issue.body:
This change introduces a user extensions for rule definitions.

**Problem**
As a user of Spectral, we want to keep additional metadata close to the rule definitions. E.g. when this rule is introduced, who is responsible, etc.

**Solution**
As it's not possible to foresee what kind of metadata users might need, therefore introducing additional fields with a concrete specificity doesn't scale and will pollute the Rule interface.

The main idea behind this solution is to give Spectral users a way to define custom extensions similar to `x-` attributes in OpenAPI documents. In this change, the new property `extensions` is introduced in the rule type which can be used by users to define any user's payload inside.

Alternative idea for the property name: `metadata`.

**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [ ] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

**Additional information**
The new field is not supported by the `print` utility. As the type of the extensions properties is unknown, it might be challenging to print it via `treeify`. Since this utility is only used for testing purposes, it seems to be okay to ignore the new property in this utility function. The similar situation is with `toJSON()`.

comment.body:
:tada: This PR is included in version @stoplight/spectral-ruleset-bundler-v1.5.0 :tada:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-ruleset-bundler/v/1.5.0)

issue.title: feat(core): support end-user extensions in the rule definitions
issue.body:
This change introduces a user extensions for rule definitions.

**Problem**
As a user of Spectral, we want to keep additional metadata close to the rule definitions. E.g. when this rule is introduced, who is responsible, etc.

**Solution**
As it's not possible to foresee what kind of metadata users might need, therefore introducing additional fields with a concrete specificity doesn't scale and will pollute the Rule interface.

The main idea behind this solution is to give Spectral users a way to define custom extensions similar to `x-` attributes in OpenAPI documents. In this change, the new property `extensions` is introduced in the rule type which can be used by users to define any user's payload inside.

Alternative idea for the property name: `metadata`.

**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [ ] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

**Additional information**
The new field is not supported by the `print` utility. As the type of the extensions properties is unknown, it might be challenging to print it via `treeify`. Since this utility is only used for testing purposes, it seems to be okay to ignore the new property in this utility function. The similar situation is with `toJSON()`.

comment.body:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-core/v/1.16.0)

payload.description: Common typings for the Stoplight ecosystem.
Nightly pre-releases of Studio Desktop https://github.com/stoplightio/studio

issue.title: Unable to use a spectral file located in Enterprise Github with a token parameter
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When trying to use a spectral lint file that requires a token param, Spectral throws an unexpected error

```
Error running Spectral!
Error #1: Unexpected token (Note that you need plugins to import files that are not JavaScript)
          at error            …hared/rollup.js:198  base = Object.assig…
          at error            …red/rollup.js:12555  return error(props);
          at tryParse         …red/rollup.js:12932  return this.error({ 
          at setSource        …red/rollup.js:12837  ast = this.tryParse…
          at addModuleSource  …red/rollup.js:22311  module.setSource(aw…
```

**To Reproduce**

1. Create a GitHub repository and place a spectral file there, like this:
    * style.yaml
```
extends: spectral:oas
rules:
  oas3-api-costcenter:
    description: There must be x-cost-center.
    given: $
    severity: error
    then:
      field: x-cost-center
      function: truthy

  oas3-api-businessid:
    description: There must be x-business-id.
    given: $
    severity: error
    then:
      field: x-business-id
      function: truthy
``` 
2. Go to the raw view of that spectral file and copy the url, it should have a token in it
2. Create a local folder with a "src" folder and a basic api-schema.json file that has an oas schema
3. Run this CLI command 'spectral lint "./src/api-schema.json" --ruleset {url with token from step 2} --verbose'
4. See error
```
Error running Spectral!
Error #1: Unexpected token (Note that you need plugins to import files that are not JavaScript)
          at error            …hared/rollup.js:198  base = Object.assig…
          at error            …red/rollup.js:12555  return error(props);
          at tryParse         …red/rollup.js:12932  return this.error({ 
          at setSource        …red/rollup.js:12837  ast = this.tryParse…
          at addModuleSource  …red/rollup.js:22311  module.setSource(aw…
```

**Expected behavior**
I would expect that Spectral would be able to ingest this file as a standard curl command shows the file as it should be.  Additionally, if I pull the file down locally and put it in the repo, it runs fine.

**Environment (remove any that are not applicable):**
 - Library version: Spectral v6.5.1
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Browser: n/a

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

comment.body:
:tada: This issue has been resolved in version @stoplight/spectral-cli-v6.6.0 :tada:

The release is available on [npm package (@latest dist-tag)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@stoplight/spectral-cli/v/6.6.0)

issue.title: Peer dependency incorrectly met when using Yarn 3.x
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I upgraded to yarn 3.x and now I have a project that is showing this error 

```sh
$ yarn install
➤ YN0000: ┌ Resolution step
➤ YN0002: │ @stoplight/spectral-cli@npm:6.3.0 doesn't provide rollup (p8903b), requested by @rollup/plugin-commonjs
➤ YN0000: │ Some peer dependencies are incorrectly met; run yarn explain peer-requirements <hash> for details, where <hash> is the six-letter p-prefixed code
➤ YN0000: └ Completed
```

**To Reproduce**

Create a project with `@stoplight/spectral-cli` as a devDependency and run `$ yarn install` with the latest version of yarn.

**Expected behavior**
No peer dependency error

**Environment (remove any that are not applicable):**
 - OS: macOS

comment.body:

issue.title: refactor(rulesets): remove unused rules style param
issue.body:
**Checklist**

- [x] Tests added / updated
- [x] Docs added / updated

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

We have discussed removing the style parameter becasue it has not proved very useful compared to simply using Error and Warning, or splitting rules into multiple rulesets for different purposes or strictnesses. 

I had thought this would be a breaking change, but the more I look at it, the less I can see it being used in any way for anything. Perhaps we use it in Studio but as far as Spectral is concerned I am not sure this is breaking. Rulesets will still validate because JSON Schema doesn't care about extra properties.

**Screenshots**

If applicable, add screenshots or gifs to help demonstrate the changes. If not applicable, remove this screenshots section before creating the PR.

**Additional context**

Add any other context about the pull request here. Remove this section if there is no additional context.
